Prerequisites for AI-1

‚ñ∑Content Prerequisites
                The mandatory
courses
                in CS@FAU; Sem. 1-4, in particular:


‚ñ∑Course
                ‚ÄúAlgorithmen und Datenstrukturen‚Äù.(Algorithms & Data Structures)


‚ñ∑Course

‚ñ∑Course
                ‚ÄúBerechenbarkeit und Formale Sprachen‚Äù.(Theoretical CS)


‚ñ∑Skillset Prerequisite
                Coping with
mathematical
                formulation of the structures


‚ñ∑Mathematics
                is the language of science(in particular
computer science)


‚ñ∑It allows us to be very precise about what we mean.
(good for you)


‚ñ∑Intuition
(take them with a kilo of salt)


‚ñ∑This is what I assume you know!(I have to assume something)


‚ñ∑In most cases, the dependency on these is partial and ‚Äúin spirit‚Äù.


‚ñ∑If you have not taken these (or do not remember), read up on them as needed!


‚ñ∑Real Prerequisites
                Motivation, interest, curiosity, hard work.(AI-1 is non-trivial)


‚ñ∑You can do this course if you want!(and I hope you are successful)

NOT a Resource for : LLMs ‚Äî AI-based tools like ChatGPT

‚ñ∑
                  A
large language model
                  (LLM) is a computational model capable of language generation or other natural language processing tasks.


‚ñ∑
                  OpenAI‚Äôs GPT, Google‚Äôs Bard, and Meta‚Äôs Llama.


‚ñ∑
                  A
chatbot
                  is a software application or web interface that is designed to mimic human conversation through text or voice interactions. Modern
chatbots
                  are usually based on
LLMs.


‚ñ∑ChatGPT talks about AI-1(but remains vague)




‚ñ∑Note
LLM-based
chatbots
                  invent
every word!(suprpisingly often correct)


‚ñ∑In the AI-1 exam
                  ChatGPT scores ca.
50%
                  of the points.


‚ñ∑ChatGPT can almost pass the exam ...(We could award it a Master‚Äôs degree)


‚ñ∑But can you?
(the AI-1 exams will be in person on paper)


You will only pass the exam, if you can do AI-1 yourself!


‚ñ∑Intuition
                  AI tools like GhatGPT, CoPilot, etc.(see also [She24])


‚ñ∑can help you solve problems,
(valuable tools in production situations)


‚ñ∑hinders
learning
                  if used for homeworks/quizzes, etc.
(like driving instead of jogging)


‚ñ∑What (not) to do
(to get most of the brave new AI-supported world)


‚ñ∑try out these tools to get a first-hand intuition what they can/cannot do


‚ñ∑challenge yourself while learning so that you can also do it
(mind over matter!)

URIs

function

URIs

interactions

text

learners

Learner Data and Privacy in
ALeA

‚ñ∑Observation
Learning support services
                  in
ALeA
                  use the
learner model; they


‚ñ∑need the
learner model
                  data to adapt to the invidivual
learner!


‚ñ∑collect
learner
                  interaction data(to update the
learner model)


‚ñ∑Consequence
                  You need to be
logged in
                  (via your
FAU IDM
                  credentials) for useful
learning support services!


‚ñ∑Problem
Learner model
                  data is highly sensitive
personal data!


‚ñ∑ALeA
                    Promise
                  The
ALeA
                  team does the utmost to keep your
personal data
                  safe.
(SSO
                      via
FAU IDM/eduGAIN,
ALeA
trust zone)


‚ñ∑ALeA
                    Privacy Axioms


1.ALeA
                  only collects
learner models
                  data about
logged in
users.


2.Personally identifiable
learner model
                  data is only accessible to its subject
(delegation possible)


3.Learners
                  can always query the
learner model
                  about its data.


4.All
learner model
                  data can be purged without negative consequences (except usability deterioration)


5.Logging into
ALeA
                  is completely optional.


‚ñ∑Observation
Authentication
                  for bonus
quizzes
                  are somewhat less optional, but you can always purge the
learner model
                  later.

Strong AI vs. Narrow AI

‚ñ∑
                  With the term
narrow AI
                  (also
weak AI,
instrumental AI,
applied AI) we refer to the use of software to study or accomplish
specific
                  problem solving or reasoning tasks
(e.g. playing
chess/go, controlling elevators, composing music, ...)


‚ñ∑
                  With the term
strong AI
                  (also
full AI,
AGI) we denote the quest for software performing at the full range of human cognitive abilities.


‚ñ∑
                  Problems requiring
strong AI
                  to solve are called
AI hard, and
AI complete, iff
AGI
                  should be able to solve them all.


‚ñ∑In short
                  We can characterize the difference intuitively:


‚ñ∑narrow AI: What (most)
computer scientists
                  think AI is / should be.


‚ñ∑strong AI: What
Hollywood
                  authors think AI is / should be.


‚ñ∑Needless to saywe are only going to cover
narrow AI
                  in this
course!

                  The
Prolog
interpreter
                  employs top-down, left-right
depth first search, concretely,
Prolog search:


‚ñ∑works on the
subgoals
                  in left right order.


‚ñ∑matches
                  first
query
                  with the
head
literals
                  of the
clauses
                  in the
program
                  in top-down order.


‚ñ∑if there are no
matches,
fail
                  and
backtracks
                  to the (chronologically) last
backtrack point.


‚ñ∑otherwise
backchain
                  on the first
match, keep the other
matches
                  in mind for
backtracking
                  via
backtrack points.


We say that a
goal
ùê∫
matches
                  a
head
ùêª,
iff
                  we can make them
equal
                  by replacing
variables
                  in
ùêª
                  with
terms.


‚ñ∑We can force
backtracking
                  to
compute
                  more
answers
                  by typing
;.

                  that specifies ‚Äî given the current cell content and internal state ‚Äî what the subsequent internal state will be, how what the R/W head does (write a symbol and/or move). Some internal states are
accepting.


‚ñ∑
Decision problems

ùêçùêè
                  if there is a
non deterministic Turing machine
                  that halts with an answer after

polynomial
                  in the size of its input. Accepts if
at least one
                  of the possible runs accepts.


‚ñ∑
Decision problems

ùêçùêèùêíùêèùêÄùêÇùêÑ, if there is a
non deterministic Turing machine

space

‚ñ∑NP vs. PSPACE
                  Non-deterministic
polynomial

ùêèùêíùêèùêÄùêÇùêÑ=ùêçùêèùêíùêèùêÄùêÇùêÑ, and hence (trivially)
ùêçùêè‚äÜùêèùêíùêèùêÄùêÇùêÑ.

AI

                Four possible answers/facets: Systems that


think¬†like¬†humans¬†think¬†rationallyact¬†like¬†humans¬†act¬†rationally


expressed by four different definitions/quotes:



Humanly


Rational
Thinking¬†
‚ÄúThe exciting new effort to make computers think ...machines with human-like minds‚Äù[Hau85]

‚ÄúThe formalization of mental faculties in terms of computational models‚Äù[CM85]

Acting¬†
‚ÄúThe art of creating machines that perform actions requiring

                                    when performed by people‚Äù[Kur90]


‚ÄúThe branch of CS concerned with the automation of appropriate behavior in complex situations‚Äù[LS93]




‚ñ∑Idea

‚ñ∑Thinking Humanly

‚ñ∑Thinking Rationally

‚ñ∑Introduced by Alan Turing (1950) ‚ÄúComputing machinery and intelligence‚Äù [Tur50]:


‚ñ∑‚ÄúCan machines think?‚Äù

‚àí
‚Üí
              ‚ÄúCan machines behave intelligently?‚Äù


‚ñ∑
                  The
Turing test

imitation game
                  over teletext
(arbitrary topic)




‚ñ∑It was predicted that by 2000, a machine might have a
30%
              chance of fooling a lay person for 5 minutes.


‚ñ∑Note
                  In [Tur50], Alan Turing


‚ñ∑anticipated all major arguments against
AI
                  in following 50 years and


‚ñ∑suggested major components of

‚ñ∑Problem

constructive, or amenable to

                  analysis!

Thinking humanly: Cognitive Science

‚ñ∑1960s
‚Äúcognitive revolution‚Äù: information processing psychology replaced prevailing orthodoxy of
behaviorism.


‚ñ∑Requires scientific theories of internal activities of the brain


‚ñ∑What level of abstraction? ‚ÄúKnowledge‚Äù or ‚Äúcircuits‚Äù?


‚ñ∑How to validate?
                  Requires


1.Predicting and testing behavior of human subjects or(top-down)


2.Direct identification from neurological data.(bottom-up)


‚ñ∑
Cognitive science
                  is the interdisciplinary,
scientific
study
                  of the
mind
                  and its processes. It examines the nature, the tasks, and the functions of
cognition.


‚ñ∑
Cognitive neuroscience
                  studies the biological processes and aspects that underlie
cognition, with a specific focus on the neural connections in the brain which are involved in mental processes.


‚ñ∑Both approaches/disciplines are now distinct from
AI.


‚ñ∑Both share with
AI
              the following characteristic:
the available theories do not explain (or engender) anything resembling human-level general
intelligence


‚ñ∑Hence, all three fields share one principal direction!

Rationality

‚ñ∑Idea
                  Try to design
agents
                  that are successful!(aka. ‚Äúdo the right thing‚Äù)


‚ñ∑Problem
                  What do we mean by ‚Äúsuccessful‚Äù, how do we measure ‚Äúsuccess‚Äù?


‚ñ∑
                  A
performance measure
                  is a
function
                  that evaluates a sequence of
environments.


‚ñ∑
                  A
performance measure
                  for a vacuum cleaner could


‚ñ∑award one point per ‚Äúsquare‚Äù cleaned up in time
ùëá?


‚ñ∑award one point per clean ‚Äúsquare‚Äù per time step, minus one per move?


‚ñ∑penalize for
>ùëò
                  dirty squares?


‚ñ∑
                  An
agent
                  is called
rational, if it chooses whichever
action
maximizes
                  the
expected value
                  of the
performance measure
                  given the
percept
                  sequence to date.


‚ñ∑Critical Observation
                  We only need to
maximize
                  the
expected value, not the actual
value
                  of the
performance measure!


‚ñ∑Question
                  Why is
rationality
                  a good quality to aim for?



Michael¬†Kohlhase:
Artificial¬†Intelligence¬†112024-12-14

Consequences of
Rationality:
Exploration,
Learning,
Autonomy

‚ñ∑Note
                  A
rational
agent
                  need not be perfect:


‚ñ∑It only needs to
maximize
expected value
(rational
‚â†
                      omniscient)


‚ñ∑need not predict e.g. very unlikely but catastrophic events in the future


‚ñ∑Percepts
                  may not supply all relevant information(rational
‚â†
                      clairvoyant)


‚ñ∑if we cannot perceive things we do not need to react to them.


‚ñ∑but we may need to try to find out about hidden dangers(exploration)


‚ñ∑Action
                  outcomes may not be as expected(rational
‚â†
                      successful)


‚ñ∑but we may need to take
action
                  to ensure that they do (more often)(learning)


‚ñ∑Note
Rationality
                  may entail
exploration,
learning,
autonomy
(depending on the environment / task)


‚ñ∑
                  An
agent
                  is called
autonomous, if it does not rely on the prior knowledge about the
environment
                  of the designer.


‚ñ∑Autonomy
              avoids fixed behaviors that can become unsuccessful in a changing
environment.(anything else would be
irrational)


‚ñ∑The
agent
              may have to
learn
              all relevant traits, invariants, properties of the
environment
              and
actions.

...


‚ñ∑Sensors

...

environment:

efficiency


‚ñ∑Environment: current and future WWW sites, vendors, shippers


‚ñ∑Actuators: display to user, follow
URL, fill in form


‚ñ∑Sensors:
HTML

Michael¬†Kohlhase:
Artificial¬†Intelligence¬†112024-12-15

Environment types

‚ñ∑
Agent
                  design is largely determined by the
type
                  of
environment
                  it is intended for.


‚ñ∑ProblemThere is a vast number of possible kinds of
environments
                  in
AI.


‚ñ∑Solution
                  Classify along a few ‚Äúdimensions‚Äù.
(independent characteristics)


‚ñ∑
                  For an
agent
ùëé
                  we classify the
environment
ùëí
                  of
ùëé
                  by its
type, which is one of the following. We call
ùëí


1.fully observable, iff the
ùëé‚Äôs sensors give it access to the complete
state
                  of the
environment
                  at any point in time, else
partially observable.


2.deterministic, iff the next
state
                  of the
environment
                  is completely determined by the current
state
                  and
ùëé‚Äôs
action, else
stochastic.


3.episodic, iff
ùëé‚Äôs experience is divided into atomic
episodes, where it perceives and then performs a single
action. Crucially, the next
episode
                  does not depend on previous ones.
Non-episodic
environments
                  are called
sequential.


4.dynamic, iff the
environment
                  can change without an
action
                  performed by
ùëé, else
static. If the
environment
                  does not change but
ùëé‚Äôs performance measure does, we call
ùëí
semidynamic.


5.discrete, iff the sets of
ùëí‚Äôs state and
ùëé‚Äôs
actions
                  are
countable, else
continuous.


6.single-agent, iff only
ùëé
                  acts on
ùëí; else
multi-agent(when must we count parts of
ùëí
                      as
agents?)



Michael¬†Kohlhase:
Artificial¬†Intelligence¬†112024-12-14

Environment Types (Examples)

‚ñ∑Some
environments
                  classified:


Solitaire¬†Backgammon¬†Internet¬†shopping¬†Taxi¬†fully¬†observable¬†No¬†Yes¬†No¬†No¬†deterministic¬†Yes¬†No¬†Partly¬†No¬†episodic¬†No¬†Yes¬†No¬†No¬†static¬†Yes¬†Semi¬†Semi¬†No¬†discrete¬†Yes¬†Yes¬†Yes¬†No¬†single-agent¬†Yes¬†No¬†Yes¬†(except¬†auctions)¬†No¬†


‚ñ∑Note
                  Take the example above with a grain of salt. There are often multiple interpretations that yield different classifications and different
agents.(agent designer‚Äôs choice)


‚ñ∑Seen as a
multi-agent
game,
chess
                  is
deterministic, as a
single-agent
game, it is
stochastic.


‚ñ∑The real world is (of course) a
partially observable,
stochastic,
sequential,
dynamic,
continuous, and
multi-agent
environment.(worst case for
AI)


‚ñ∑Preview
                  We will concentrate on the ‚Äúeasy‚Äù environment types (fully observable,
deterministic,
episodic,
static, and
single-agent) in AI-1 and extend them to ‚Äúrealworld‚Äù-compatible ones in AI-2.

Agent
              Types

agents

Agents

‚ñ∑Concretely
                  We will use the following two concepts to describe problems


‚ñ∑States: A set of possible situations in our problem domain(=^

‚ñ∑Actions: that get us from one

agents)

goal state.

solutions
                  from
problem formulations.


‚ñ∑
                  In
offline
problem solving
                  an
agent
                  computing an action sequence based complete knowledge of the

‚ñ∑

‚ñ∑
                  In
online
problem solving
                  an
agent

                  We largely restrict ourselves to

procedure¬†Tree_Search¬†(problem,strategy)

end¬†loop
end¬†procedure

                  (DFS) is the

                  from the
stack
                  and continuing the
search
                  with the new top
element
                  of the
stack
                  (a
backtrack point
                  by construction) is called
backtracking, and correspondingly the
DFS
algorithm
backtracking search.


‚ñ∑Note
Depth first search
                  can perform
infinite
cyclic
                  excursionsNeed a
finite, non cyclic
state space
                  (or repeated state checking)

Tree Search vs. Graph Search

‚ñ∑We have only covered
tree search algorithms.


‚ñ∑States
              duplicated in
nodes
              are a huge problem for
efficiency.


‚ñ∑
                  A
graph search
algorithm
                  is a variant of a
tree search algorithm
                  that
prunes
nodes
                  whose
state
                  has already been considered (duplicate pruning), essentially using a
DAG
data structure.


‚ñ∑
Tree search
                  is memory intensive it has to store the
fringe
                  so keeping a list of ‚Äúexplored states‚Äù does not lose much.


‚ñ∑Graph versions
              of all the
tree search algorithms
              considered here exist, but are more difficult to understand (and to prove properties about).


‚ñ∑The (time complexity) properties are largely stable under
duplicate pruning.(no gain in the worst case)


‚ñ∑
                  We speak of a
search algorithm, when we do not want to distinguish whether it is a
tree
                  or
graph search
algorithm.
(difference considered an
implementation
                      detail)

Heuristic Functions: The Eternal Trade-Off

‚ñ∑
                  ‚ÄúDistance Estimate‚Äù?(‚Ñé

‚ñ∑We also want it to be fast, i.e., a small overhead for computing
‚Ñé.


‚ñ∑These two wishes are in

‚ñ∑‚Ñé=‚Ñé*: perfectly accurate, overhead
=^
                  solving the problem in the first place.


‚ñ∑
                  We need to trade off the accuracy of
‚Ñé
                  against the overhead for computing it.

‚ñ∑

1.base case

‚ñ∑
                  We call a

‚ñ∑
                  In

search algorithms

‚ñ∑Alternative
                  Keep only one (or a few)

                  at a time


‚ñ∑‚§≥
                  no

                  exploration of all options,
‚§≥
incomplete.

Local Search Problems

‚ñ∑Idea
                  Sometimes the
path
                  to the

‚ñ∑8 Queens Problem
                                  Place 8
queens
                                  on a
chess
                                  board, so that no two
queens
                                  threaten each other.


‚ñ∑
                                  This problem has various solutions
(the one of the right isn‚Äôt one of them)


‚ñ∑
                                  A
local search algorithm
                                  is a

state, the
current state
                                  (rather than multiple
paths).(advantage:
constant
space)







¬†

‚ñ∑
                  Typically
local search algorithms
                  only move to
successor
                  of the
current state, and do not retain search
paths.


‚ñ∑Applications include: integrated circuit design, factory-floor layout, job-shop scheduling, portfolio management, fleet deployment,...

Hill-climbing (gradient ascent/descent)

‚ñ∑Idea
                  Start anywhere and go in the direction of the steepest ascent.


‚ñ∑
Hill climbing
                  (also
gradient ascent) is a
local search algorithm
                  that iteratively selects the best
successor:


procedure¬†Hill‚ÄïClimbing¬†(problem)¬†/*¬†a¬†state¬†that¬†is¬†a¬†local¬†minimum¬†*/
local¬†current,¬†neighbor¬†/*¬†nodes¬†*/
current¬†:=¬†Make‚ÄïNode(Initial‚ÄïState[problem])
loop
neighbor¬†:=¬†<a¬†highest‚Äïvalued¬†successor¬†of¬†current>
if¬†Value[neighbor]¬†<¬†Value[current]¬†return¬†[current]¬†end¬†if
current¬†:=¬†neighbor
end¬†loop
end¬†procedure

‚ñ∑IntuitionLike
best first search
                  without memory.


‚ñ∑Works, if solutions are dense and
local maxima
              can be escaped.

Michael¬†Kohlhase:

Hill-climbing



‚ñ∑Problem
                                  Depending on
initial state, can get stuck on

                                  and plateaux.


‚ñ∑
                                  ‚ÄúHill-climbing search is like climbing Everest in thick fog with amnesia‚Äù.








¬†

‚ñ∑Idea
                  Escape
local maxima
                  by allowing some ‚Äúbad‚Äù or random moves.


‚ñ∑local search,

‚ñ∑Properties

‚ñ∑Sometimes performs well in practice(if (optimal) solutions are dense)



Michael¬†Kohlhase:
Artificial¬†Intelligence¬†132024-12-14

Simulated annealing (Idea)



‚ñ∑
Ridges
                                  are ascending successions of
local maxima.


‚ñ∑Problem
                                  They are extremely difficult to bv navigate for
local search algorithms.


‚ñ∑Idea
                                  Escape
local maxima
                                  by allowing some ‚Äúbad‚Äù moves, but gradually decrease their size and frequency.







¬†

‚ñ∑Annealing is the process of heating steel and let it cool gradually to give it time to grow an optimal cristal structure.


‚ñ∑Simulated annealing
              is like shaking a ping pong ball occasionally on a bumpy surface to free it.(so it does not get stuck)


‚ñ∑Devised by Metropolis et al for physical process modelling [Met+53]


‚ñ∑Widely used in VLSI layout, airline scheduling, etc.

Simulated annealing (Implementation)

‚ñ∑
                  The following
algorithm
                  is called
simulated annealing:


procedure¬†Simulated‚ÄïAnnealing¬†(problem,schedule)¬†/*¬†a¬†solution¬†state¬†*/
local¬†node,¬†next¬†/*¬†nodes¬†*/
local¬†T¬†/*¬†a¬†‚Äò‚Äòtemperature‚Äô‚Äô¬†controlling¬†prob.~of¬†downward¬†steps¬†*/
current¬†:=¬†Make‚ÄïNode(Initial‚ÄïState[problem])
for¬†t¬†:=1¬†to¬†‚àû
T¬†:=¬†schedule[t]
if¬†T¬†=¬†0¬†return¬†current¬†end¬†if
next¬†:=¬†<a¬†randomly¬†selected¬†successor¬†of¬†current>
‚àÜ(E)¬†:=¬†Value[next]‚ÄïValue[current]
if¬†‚àÜ(E)¬†>¬†0¬†current¬†:=¬†next
else
current¬†:=¬†next¬†<only¬†with¬†probability>¬†ùëí‚àÜ(ùê∏)/ùëá
end¬†if
end¬†for
end¬†procedure

A
schedule
                  is a mapping from time to ‚Äútemperature‚Äù.

Michael¬†Kohlhase:

Minimax, Pro and Contra

‚ñ∑Minimax advantages


‚ñ∑Minimax
                is the simplest possible (reasonable)
search algorithm
                for games.

(If any of you sat down, prior to this
lecture, to
implement
                a Tic-Tac-Toe player, chances are you either looked this up on Wikipedia, or invented it in the process.)


‚ñ∑Returns an
optimal
action, assuming perfect opponent play.


‚ñ∑No matter how the opponent plays, the
utility
                of the
terminal state
                reached will be at least the value computed for the
root.


‚ñ∑If the opponent plays perfectly, exactly that value will be reached.


‚ñ∑There‚Äôs no need to re-run
minimax
                for every
game state: Run it once,
offline
                before the game starts. During the actual game, just follow the branches taken in the
tree. Whenever it‚Äôs your turn, choose an
action
maximizing
                the value of the
successor
states.


‚ñ∑Minimax
                  disadvantages
It‚Äôs completely infeasible in practice.


‚ñ∑When the
search tree
                is too large, we need to limit the search depth and apply an
evaluation function
                to the cut off
states.

ùë†
                      with
dp(ùë†)=ùëë.

                  An

ùëì

game states
                  to numbers:


‚ñ∑ùëì(ùë†)

ùë†
                  (as would be computed by unlimited-depth
minimax
                  for
ùë†).


‚ñ∑If
cut-off state
                  is
terminal: Just use
ùë¢^
                  instead of
ùëì.


‚ñ∑Analogy to
heuristic functions

??): We want
ùëì

contradiction
‚§≥
              need to trade-off accuracy against overhead.


‚ñ∑In typical game playing
algorithms

ùëì

(usually no good methods known for computing accurate
ùëì)

The Horizon Problem

‚ñ∑Problem
                  Critical aspects of the game can be cut off by the
horizon.We call this the

‚ñ∑







‚ñ∑Who‚Äôs gonna win here?


‚ñ∑White
                                    wins (pawn
                                    cannot be prevented from becoming a
queen.)


‚ñ∑Black
                                    has a
+4
                                    advantage in material, so if we cut-off here then our
evaluation function
                                    will say ‚Äú100%,
black
                                    wins‚Äù.


‚ñ∑The loss for
black

                                    to

king.

So, How Deeply to Search?

‚ñ∑Goal
                  In given time, search as deeply as possible.


‚ñ∑Problem
                  Very difficult to predict search
running time.(need an
anytime algorithm)


‚ñ∑Solution
Iterative deepening search.


‚ñ∑Search with
depth limit
ùëë=1,2,3,...


‚ñ∑When time is up: return result of deepest completed search.


‚ñ∑Better Solution
                  The
quiescent search
algorithm
                  uses a dynamically adapted search depth
ùëë: It searches more deeply in
unquiet
                  positions, where value of
evaluation function
                  changes a lot in neighboring
states.


‚ñ∑
                  In
quiescent search
                  for
chess:


‚ñ∑piece exchange situations (‚Äúyou take mine, I take yours‚Äù) are very
unquiet


‚ñ∑‚§≥
                  Keep searching until the end of the piece exchange is reached.

Michael¬†Kohlhase:

How to Guide the Search in
MCTS?

‚ñ∑How to
sample?
                  What exactly is ‚Äúrandom‚Äù?


‚ñ∑Classical formulation
                  balance exploitation vs. exploration.


‚ñ∑Exploitation: Prefer moves that have high average already
(interesting regions of state space)


‚ñ∑Exploration: Prefer moves that have not been tried a lot yet
(don‚Äôt overlook other, possibly better, options)


‚ñ∑UCT: ‚ÄúUpper Confidence bounds applied to Trees‚Äù [KS06].


‚ñ∑Inspired by Multi-Armed Bandit (as in: Casino) problems.


‚ñ∑Basically a formula defining the balance. Very popular (buzzword).


‚ñ∑Recent critics (e.g. [FD14]):
Exploitation
              in search is very different from the Casino, as the ‚Äúaccumulated rewards‚Äù are fictitious (we‚Äôre only thinking about the game, not actually playing and winning/losing all the time).

‚ñ∑Neural Networks in AlphaGo


‚ñ∑Policy networks: Given a state
ùë†, output a probability distribution over the actions applicable in
ùë†.


‚ñ∑Value networks: Given a state
ùë†, output a number estimating the game value of
ùë†.


‚ñ∑Combination with MCTS


‚ñ∑Policy networks bias the action choices within the
MCTS tree
                  (and hence the
leaf
state
                  selection), and bias the random
samples.


‚ñ∑Value networks are an additional source of state values in the
MCTS tree, along with the random
samples.

Michael¬†Kohlhase:
Artificial¬†Intelligence¬†122024-12-15

Summary

‚ñ∑Games (2-player turn-taking zero-sum discrete and finite games) can be understood as a simple extension of classical
search problems.


‚ñ∑Each player tries to reach a terminal state with the best possible
utility
            (maximal vs. minimal).


‚ñ∑Minimax
            searches the game depth-first, max‚Äôing and min‚Äôing at the respective turns of each player. It yields perfect play, but takes time
ùí™(ùëèùëë)
            where
ùëè
            is the branching factor and
ùëë
            the search depth.


‚ñ∑Except in trivial games (Tic-Tac-Toe),
minimax
            needs a depth limit and apply an
evaluation function
            to estimate the value of the cut-off states.


‚ñ∑Alpha-beta search remembers the best values achieved for each player elsewhere in the tree already, and
prunes
            out sub-trees that won‚Äôt be reached in the game.


‚ñ∑Monte Carlo tree search
            (MCTS)
samples
            game branches, and averages the findings.
AlphaGo
            controls this using
neural networks:
evaluation function
            (‚Äúvalue network‚Äù), and action filter (‚Äúpolicy network‚Äù).

                  Who‚Äôs going to play against who, when and where?

state

              that supports
goal test, eval,
successor state, ...

‚ñ∑Constraint Satisfaction Problem


‚ñ∑
                  A
CSP

                  is called

ùúë‚àäŒ†ùõæ.ùíÆùõæ

ùë•‚Ü¶ùë£
                  not

ùúë.

assignment)

Œ†ùõæ.‚Ñêùõæ: the
empty assignment
ùúñ.

Œ†ùõæ.ùí¢ùõæ: the
total
assignments

Summary & Preview

‚ñ∑Summary of ‚ÄúCSP
            as Search‚Äù:


‚ñ∑Constraint networks
ùõæ
            consist of
variables, associated with
finite
domains, and
constraints
            which are binary
relations
            specifying permissible
value
pairs.


‚ñ∑A
variable assignment
ùëé
            maps some
variables
            to
values.
ùëé
            is
consistent
            if it complies with all
constraints. A
consistent
total
assignment
            is a
solution.


‚ñ∑The
constraint satisfaction problem
            (CSP) consists in finding a
solution
            for a
constraint network. This has numerous applications including, e.g., scheduling and timetabling.


‚ñ∑Backtracking search
assigns
variable
            one by one,
pruning
inconsistent
variable assignments.


‚ñ∑Variable orderings
            in
backtracking
            can dramatically reduce the
size
            of the
search tree.
Value orderings
            have this potential (only) in
solvable
            sub trees.

                and
decomposition, for improved
efficiency.

                power.

‚ñ∑When: At every
recursive call
                of
backtracking.


‚ñ∑Effect: Strong

                The more complex the

inference
                reasons about
the network restricted to the commitments already made in the
search.

Conclusion & Summary

‚ñ∑ùõæ

‚ñ∑Inference
            tightens
ùõæ
            without losing
equivalence, during
backtracking search. This reduces the amount of search needed; that benefit must be traded off against the
running time
            overhead for making the
inferences.


‚ñ∑Forward checking
            removes values
conflicting
            with an assignment already made.


‚ñ∑Arc consistency
            removes values that do not comply with any value still available at the other end of a
constraint. This
subsumes
forward checking.


‚ñ∑The
constraint graph
            captures the dependencies between
variables. Separate
connected
components
            can be solved independently. Networks with
acyclic
constraint graphs
            can be solved in low order
polynomial time.


‚ñ∑A
cutset
            is a subset of
variables
            removing which renders the
constraint graph
acyclic.
Cutset conditioning
backtracks
            only on such a
cutset, and solves a sub-problem with
acyclic
constraint graph
            at each search
leaf.

‚å©ùëâ,ùê∑,ùê∂‚å™

                  is

‚àÜ'¬†:=¬†a¬†copy¬†of¬†‚àÜ;¬†ùêº'¬†:=¬†ùêº

/*¬†Splitting¬†Rule:¬†*/

ùêº''¬†:=¬†ùêº'¬†extended¬†with¬†one¬†truth¬†value¬†for¬†ùëÉ;¬†‚àÜ'':=¬†a¬†copy¬†of¬†‚àÜ';¬†simplify¬†‚àÜ''

Properties of DPLL

‚ñ∑Unsatisfiable case
                What can we say if ‚Äúunsatisfiable‚Äù is returned?


‚ñ∑In this case, we know that
‚àÜ
                is
unsatisfiable: Unit propagation is
sound, in the sense that it does not reduce the set of solutions.


‚ñ∑Satisfiable case
                What can we say when a partial interpretation
ùêº
                is returned?


‚ñ∑Any extension of
ùêº
                to a complete interpretation satisfies
‚àÜ. (By construction,
ùêº
                suffices to satisfy all
clauses.)


‚ñ∑D√©j√† Vu, Anybody?


‚ñ∑DPLL
=^
backtracking with inference, where inference
=^
unit propagation.


‚ñ∑Unit propagation
                is
sound: It does not reduce the set of solutions.


‚ñ∑Running time
                is
exponential
                in worst case, good variable/value selection strategies required.

UP
=^
              Unit Resolution

‚ñ∑Observation
                  The
unit propagation
                  (UP) rule corresponds to a
calculus:


while¬†‚àÜ'¬†contains¬†a¬†unit¬†clause¬†{ùëô}¬†do
extend¬†ùêº'¬†with¬†the¬†respective¬†truth¬†value¬†for¬†the¬†proposition¬†underlying¬†ùëô
simplify¬†‚àÜ'¬†/*¬†remove¬†false¬†literals¬†*/

‚ñ∑Unit Resolution
Unit resolution
                  (UR) is the
test calculus
                  consisting of the following
inference rule:
ùê∂‚à®ùëÉùõºùëÉùõΩùõº‚â†ùõΩùê∂UR

‚ñ∑Unit propagation
=^
resolution
              restricted to cases where one parent is
unit clause.


‚ñ∑Soundness
UR
                  is
refutation sound.
(since
resolution
                      is)


‚ñ∑Completeness
UR
                  is not
refutation complete
                  (alone).


‚ñ∑
(ùëÉùñ≥‚à®ùëÑùñ≥);(ùëÉùñ≥‚à®ùëÑùñ•);(ùëÉùñ•‚à®ùëÑùñ≥);(ùëÉùñ•‚à®ùëÑùñ•)

derive

empty clause
‚ñ°.


‚ñ∑UR

DPLL vs. Resolution: Discussion

‚ñ∑So What?
                  The theorem we just proved helps to
understand
DPLL:DPLL
                  is an
efficient
                  practical method for conducting
resolution proofs.


‚ñ∑In fact
DPLL
=^
tree resolution.


‚ñ∑
                  In a
tree resolution, each
derived
clause
ùê∂
                  is used only once (at its
parent).


‚ñ∑Problem
                  The same
ùê∂
                  must be
derived
                  anew every time it is used!


‚ñ∑This is a fundamental weakness
                  There are inputs
‚àÜ
                  whose shortest
tree resolution
                  proof is
exponentially
                  longer than their shortest (general)
resolution proof.


‚ñ∑Intuitively
DPLL
                  makes the same mistakes over and over again.


‚ñ∑Idea
DPLL
                  should learn from its mistakes on one search
branch, and apply the learned knowledge to other
branches.


‚ñ∑To the rescueclause learning(up next)

Summary

‚ñ∑SAT solvers
            decide satisfiability of CNF formulas. This can be used for deduction, and is highly successful as a general problem solving technique (e.g., in
verification).


‚ñ∑DPLL
=^
backtracking
            with inference performed by
unit propagation
            (UP), which iteratively instantiates
unit clauses
            and simplifies the
formula.


‚ñ∑DPLL
            proofs of unsatisfiability correspond to a restricted form of
resolution. The restriction forces
DPLL
            to ‚Äúmakes the same mistakes over again‚Äù.


‚ñ∑Implication graphs
            capture how
UP
derives
            conflicts. Their analysis enables us to do
clause learning.
DPLL
            with
clause learning
            is called
CDCL. It corresponds to full
resolution, not ‚Äúmaking the same mistakes over again‚Äù.


‚ñ∑CDCL
            is
state of the art
            in applications, routinely solving formulas with millions of propositions.


‚ñ∑In particular random formula distributions, typical problem hardness is characterized by
phase transitions.

Topics We Didn‚Äôt Cover Here

‚ñ∑Variable/value selection

‚ñ∑Local search: In space of all truth value assignments. GSAT (slide

‚ñ∑Portfolios: How to combine several
SAT solvers
efficiently?


‚ñ∑Random restarts: Tackling heavy-tailed runtime distributions.


‚ñ∑Tractable
SAT: Polynomial-time sub-classes (most prominent: 2-SAT, Horn formulas).


‚ñ∑MaxSAT: Assign weight to each
clause,
maximize
            weight of
satisfied
clauses
            (= optimization version of
SAT).


‚ñ∑Resolution special cases: There‚Äôs a universe in between unit resolution and
full resolution: trade off inference vs.,search.

Remarks

‚ñ∑Which clause(s) to learn?


‚ñ∑While we only select
choice literals, much more can be done.


‚ñ∑For any cut through the
conflict graph, with
Choice literals
                on the ‚Äúleft hand‚Äù side of the cut and the
conflict literals
                on the right-hand side, the
literals
                on the left border of the cut yield a
learnable clause.


‚ñ∑Must take care to
not learn too many
clauses
                  ...


‚ñ∑Origins of
clause learning


‚ñ∑Clause learning
                originates from ‚Äúexplanation-based (no-good) learning‚Äù developed in the CSP community.


‚ñ∑The distinguishing feature here is that the ‚Äúno-good‚Äù is a
clause:


‚ñ∑The exact same type of constraint as the rest of
‚àÜ.

Where Are the Hard Problems?

‚ñ∑So, what‚Äôs the problem
                Science is about
understanding the world.


‚ñ∑Are ‚Äúhard cases‚Äù just pathological outliers?

‚ñ∑Difficulty 2
                Search trees get very complex, and are difficult to analyze

Why

‚ñ∑Intuition


Under-Constrained:Satisfiability likelihood close to

Over-Constrained:Satisfiability likelihood close to

DPLL

Critically¬†Constrained:At the

almost-successful

Michael¬†Kohlhase:
Artificial¬†Intelligence¬†122024-12-15

The Phase Transition Conjecture

‚ñ∑
                  We say that a class
ùëÉ
                  of problems exhibits a
phase transition, if there is an
order parameter
ùëú, i.e. a structural parameter of
ùëÉ, so that almost all the hard problems of
ùëÉ
                  cluster around a
critical value
ùëê
                  of
ùëú
                  and
ùëê
                  separates one region of the problem space from another, e.g. over-constrained and under-constrained regions.


‚ñ∑Phase Transition Conjecture
                  All
ùêçùêè-complete problems exhibit at least one
phase transition.


‚ñ∑[CKT91] confirmed this for Graph Coloring and Hamiltonian Circuits. Later work confirmed it for
SAT
              (see previous slides), and for numerous other
ùêçùêè-complete problems.



Michael¬†Kohlhase:
Artificial¬†Intelligence¬†112024-12-15

Why Should
We
              Care?

‚ñ∑Enlightenment


‚ñ∑Phase transitions
                  contribute to the fundamental understanding of the behavior of search, even if it‚Äôs only in random distributions.


‚ñ∑There are interesting theoretical connections to
phase transition
                  phenomena in physics. (See
[GS05]
                  for a short summary.)


‚ñ∑Ok, but what can we use these results for?


‚ñ∑Benchmark
                    design: Choose instances from
phase transition
                  region.


‚ñ∑Commonly used in competitions etc. (In
SAT, random
phase transition
                  formulas are the most difficult for
DPLL
                  style searches.)


‚ñ∑Predicting solver performance: Yes, but very limited because:


‚ñ∑All this works only for the particular considered
distributions of instances! Not meaningful for any other instances.

Artificial¬†Intelligence¬†112024-12-15

Let‚Äôs Talk About Blocks, Baby ...

‚ñ∑Question
                  What do you see here?




‚ñ∑You say
                  ‚ÄúAll blocks are red‚Äù; ‚ÄúAll blocks are on the table‚Äù; ‚ÄúA is a block‚Äù.


‚ñ∑And now
                  Say it in
propositional logic!


‚ñ∑Answer
                  ‚ÄúisRedA‚Äù,‚ÄúisRedB‚Äù, ..., ‚ÄúonTableA‚Äù, ‚ÄúonTableB‚Äù, ..., ‚ÄúisBlockA‚Äù, ...

‚ñ∑Wait a sec!
                  Why don‚Äôt we just say, e.g., ‚ÄúAllBlocksAreRed‚Äù and ‚ÄúisBlockA‚Äù?


‚ñ∑Problem
                  Could we conclude that A is red?(No)

These statements are atomic (just strings); their inner structure (‚Äúall blocks‚Äù, ‚Äúis a block‚Äù) is not captured.


‚ñ∑Idea
Predicate Logic
                  (PL1) extends
propositional logic
                  with the ability to explicitly speak about objects and their properties.


‚ñ∑How?
                  Variables ranging over objects, predicates describing object properties, ...

‚ñ∑

                      ‚Äú‚àÄùë•.block(ùë•)‚áíred(ùë•)‚Äù; ‚Äúblock(ùêÄ)‚Äù

What is knowledge? Why Representation?

‚ñ∑Lots/all of (academic) disciplines deal with knowledge!


‚ñ∑According to Probst/Raub/Romhardt [PRR97]




For the purposes of this course
Knowledge
                  is the
information
                  necessary to support
intelligent reasoning!

‚ñ∑representation¬†can¬†be¬†used¬†to¬†determineset¬†of¬†words¬†whether¬†a¬†word¬†is¬†admissiblelist¬†of¬†words¬†the¬†rank¬†of¬†a¬†worda¬†lexicon¬†translation¬†and/or¬†grammatical¬†functionstructure¬†function¬†

Computational¬†Logic12024-12-15

Knowledge Representation vs. Data Structures

‚ñ∑Idea
                  Representation as structure
and
                  function.


‚ñ∑the
representation
                  determines the content theory(what is the data?)


‚ñ∑the
function
                  determines the process model(what do we do with the data?)


‚ñ∑Question
                  Why do we use the term ‚Äúknowledge representation‚Äù rather than


‚ñ∑data structures?(sets, lists, ... above)


‚ñ∑information representation?(it is information)


‚ñ∑Answer
No good reason other than
AI
                  practice, with the intuition that


‚ñ∑data
                  is simple and general(supports many
algorithms)


‚ñ∑knowledge
                  is complex(has distinguished process model)



:
Computational¬†Logic12024-12-15

Some Paradigms for Knowledge Representation in
AI/NLP

‚ñ∑GOFAI(good old-fashioned AI)


‚ñ∑symbolic knowledge representation, process model based on
heuristic search


‚ñ∑Statistical, corpus-based approaches.


‚ñ∑symbolic representation, process model based on
machine learning


‚ñ∑knowledge is divided into symbolic- and statistical (search) knowledge


‚ñ∑The connectionist approach


‚ñ∑sub-symbolic representation, process model based on primitive processing elements (nodes) and weighted links


‚ñ∑knowledge is only present in activation patters, etc.



:
Computational¬†Logic12024-12-14

KR Approaches/Evaluation Criteria

‚ñ∑
                  The
evaluation criteria
                  for knowledge representation approaches are:


‚ñ∑Expressive adequacy: What can be represented, what distinctions are supported.


‚ñ∑Reasoning efficiency: Can the representation support processing that generates results in acceptable speed?


‚ñ∑Primitives: What are the primitive elements of representation, are they intuitive, cognitively adequate?


‚ñ∑Meta representation: Knowledge about knowledge


‚ñ∑Completeness: The problems of reasoning with knowledge that is known to be incomplete.

Frames and Frame Axioms

‚ñ∑Problem
Effect axioms
                  are not enough.


‚ñ∑Say that the
agent
                  has an arrow at time 0, and then moves
forward
                  into
[2,1],
perceives
                  a
glitter, and knows that the
Wumpus
                  is ahead.

To evaluate the
action
shoot(1)
                  the corresponding
effect axiom
                  needs to know
havarrow(1), but cannot prove it from
havarrow(0).

Problem: The information of having an arrow has been lost in the move forward.


‚ñ∑
                  The
frame problem
                  describes that for a representation of
actions
                  we need to formalize their effects on the aspects they change, but also their non-effect on the static
frame of reference.


‚ñ∑Partial Solution(there are many many more; some better)

Frame axioms
                      formalize that particular
fluents
                      are invariant under a given
action.


‚ñ∑Problem

agent

ùëõ
actions

ùëö
fluents, we need
ùí™(ùëõùëö)

sensor
                  and
transition models.

Reminder: General Problem Solving, Pros and Cons

‚ñ∑Powerful
                  In some applications, generality is absolutely necessary.
(E.g. SAP)


‚ñ∑Quick
                  Rapid prototyping: 10s
lines
                  of problem description vs. 1000s
lines
                  of C++ code.
(E.g. language generation)


‚ñ∑Flexible
                  Adapt/maintain
the description.
(E.g. network security)


‚ñ∑Intelligent
                  Determines automatically how to solve a complex problem
efficiently!
(The ultimate goal, no?!)


‚ñ∑Efficiency loss
                  Without any domain-specific knowledge about
chess, you don‚Äôt beat Kasparov ...

‚ñ∑Trade-off between ‚Äúautomatic and general‚Äù vs. ‚Äúmanual work but
efficient‚Äù.


‚ñ∑Research Question
                  How to make fully automatic
algorithms
efficient?

planner

Partial Order Planning

‚ñ∑
                  Any
algorithm
                  that can place two
actions
                  into a
plan
                  without specifying which comes first is called as
partial order planning.


‚ñ∑Ideas
                  for
partial order planning:


‚ñ∑Organize the planning steps in a DAG that supports multiple paths from initial to goal state


‚ñ∑nodes (steps) are labeled with
actions(actions
                      can occur multiply)


‚ñ∑edges with propositions added by source and presupposed by target


acyclicity of the graph induces a partial ordering on steps. q


‚ñ∑additional temporal constraints resolve subgoal interactions and induce a linear order.


‚ñ∑Advantages
                  of
partial order planning:


‚ñ∑problems can be decomposed
‚§≥
                  can work well with non-cooperative environments.


‚ñ∑efficient
                  by least-commitment strategy


‚ñ∑causal links (edges) pinpoint unworkable subplans early.

Planning Process

Partial order planning
                  is search in the space of partial plans via the following operations:

                  one

‚ñ∑IdeaGradually move from incomplete/vague plans to complete, correct plans.backtrack

PDDL: Planning Domain Description Language

‚ñ∑
                  The
Planning Domain Description Language
                  (PDDL) is a standardized representation language for planning
benchmarks
                  in various extensions of the
STRIPS
                  formalism.


‚ñ∑
PDDL
                  is not a propositional language


‚ñ∑Representation is lifted, using
object variables
                  to be instantiated from a
finite
                  set of
objects.
(Similar to predicate logic)


‚ñ∑Action schemas
                  parameterized by
objects.


‚ñ∑Predicates
                  to be instantiated with
objects.


‚ñ∑
                  A
PDDL planning task
                  comes in two pieces


‚ñ∑The
problem file
                  gives the objects, the initial state, and the goal state.


‚ñ∑The
domain file
                  gives the predicates and the
actions.

Michael¬†Kohlhase:

Summary

‚ñ∑General problem solving attempts to develop solvers that perform well across a large class of problems.


‚ñ∑Planning, as considered here, is a form of general problem solving dedicated to the class of classical search problems. (Actually, we also address inaccessible, stochastic, dynamic, continuous, and multi-agent settings.)


‚ñ∑Heuristic search
            planning has dominated the
International Planning Competition
            (IPC). We focus on it here.


‚ñ∑STRIPS
            is the simplest possible, while reasonably expressive, language for our purposes. It uses Boolean variables (facts), and defines
actions
            in terms of precondition, add list, and delete list.


‚ñ∑PDDL is the de-facto standard language for describing planning problems.


‚ñ∑Plan existence (bounded or not) is
ùêèùêíùêèùêÄùêÇùêÑ-complete to decide for
STRIPS. If we bound
plans
            polynomially, we get down to
ùêçùêè-completeness.

Michael¬†Kohlhase:
Artificial¬†Intelligence¬†112024-12-14

Summary

‚ñ∑Heuristic search
            on classical
search problems
            relies on a
function
‚Ñé
            mapping
states
ùë†
            to an estimate
‚Ñé(ùë†)
            of their
goal state
            distance. Such
functions
‚Ñé
            are derived by solving
relaxed problems.


‚ñ∑In
planning, the
relaxed
            problems are generated and solved automatically. There are four known families of suitable relaxation methods:
abstractions,
landmarks,
critical paths, and
ignoring deletes
            (aka
delete relaxation).


‚ñ∑The
delete relaxation
            consists in dropping the
deletes
            from
STRIPS tasks. A
relaxed plan
            is a
plan
            for such a
relaxed
task.
‚Ñé+(ùë†)
            is the length of an optimal relaxed plan for
state
ùë†.
‚Ñé+
            is
ùêçùêè-hard to compute.


‚ñ∑‚Ñéùêπùêπ
            approximates
‚Ñé+
            by computing some, not necessarily optimal, relaxed plan. That is done by a forward pass (building a
relaxed planning graph), followed by a backward pass (extracting a relaxed plan).



Michael¬†Kohlhase:
Artificial¬†Intelligence¬†112024-12-15

Topics We Didn‚Äôt Cover Here

‚ñ∑Abstractions, Landmarks, Critical-Path Heuristics, Cost Partitions, Compilability between Heuristic Functions, Planning Competitions:


‚ñ∑Tractable
              fragments:
            Planning sub-classes that can be solved in polynomial time. Often identified by properties of the ‚Äúcausal graph‚Äù and ‚Äúdomain transition graphs‚Äù.


‚ñ∑Planning as SAT:
            Compile length-ùëò
            bounded plan existence into satisfiability of a CNF formula
ùúë. Extensive literature on how to obtain small
ùúë, how to schedule different values of
ùëò, how to modify the underlying SAT solver.


‚ñ∑Compilations:
            Formal framework for determining whether planning formalism
ùëã
            is (or is not) at least as expressive as planning formalism
ùëå.


‚ñ∑Admissible
pruning/decomposition methods:
            Partial-order reduction, symmetry reduction, simulation-based dominance
pruning,
factored
planning, decoupled search.


‚ñ∑Hand-tailored planning:
            Automatic planning is the extreme case where the
computer
            is given no domain knowledge other than ‚Äúphysics‚Äù. We can instead allow the user to provide search control knowledge, trading off modeling effort against search performance.


‚ñ∑Numeric planning,
temporal planning,
planning under
uncertainty
            ...

ùëè

ùëé

‚ñ∑The

‚ñ∑The

ùëú=PERC(ùë†)¬†and¬†ùë†‚àäùëè^
}

RESULT(ùëè,ùëé):={UPDATE(PRED(ùëè,ùëé),ùëú)|PossPERC(PRED(ùëè,ùëé))}

Michael¬†Kohlhase:
Artificial¬†Intelligence¬†112024-12-16

Factors in World Model Failure
‚§≥
              Monitoring

‚ñ∑Generally
                  The agent‚Äôs world model can be incorrect, because


‚ñ∑an action has a missing precondition(need a screwdriver for
remove‚Äïlid)


‚ñ∑an action misses an effect(painting a table gets paint on the floor)


‚ñ∑it is missing a state variable(amount of paint in a can: no paint
‚§≥
                      no color)


‚ñ∑no provisions for exogenous events
(someone knocks over a paint can)


‚ñ∑Observation
                  Without a way for monitoring for these, planning is very brittle.


‚ñ∑
                  There are three levels of
execution monitoring: before executing an action


‚ñ∑action monitoring
                  checks whether all preconditions still hold.


‚ñ∑plan monitoring
                  checks that the remaining plan will still succeed.


‚ñ∑goal monitoring
                  checks whether there is a better set of goals it could try to achieve.


‚ñ∑Note
??
                  was a case of
action monitoring
                  leading to replanning.

Rational Agent

‚ñ∑Idea
                  Try to design
agents
                  that are successful(do the right thing)


‚ñ∑
                  An
agent
                  is called
rational, if it chooses whichever
action
maximizes
                  the expected value of the performance measure given the
percept
                  sequence to date. This is called the
MEU principle.


‚ñ∑Note
                  A
rational
agent
                  need not be perfect


‚ñ∑only needs to
maximize
expected value
(rational
‚â†
                      omniscient)


‚ñ∑need not predict e.g. very unlikely but catastrophic events in the future


‚ñ∑percepts
                  may not supply all relevant information(Rational
‚â†
                      clairvoyant)


‚ñ∑if we cannot perceive things we do not need to react to them.


‚ñ∑but we may need to try to find out about hidden dangers(exploration)


‚ñ∑action
                  outcomes may not be as expected(rational
‚â†
                      successful)


‚ñ∑but we may need to take
action
                  to ensure that they do (more often)(learning)

‚§≥
              exploration, learning, autonomy
